results.title: [Taronga Park; Sydney Harbour Bridge; The Great Barrier Reef; Peeping at Perth]
results.creator_credit: Eric Merton, Kodak Cinegraph and Perier Films
results.brief_description:
This film contains four short tourism films edited together, possibly by Ted Parsons.

The first film shows Taronga Zoological Park in Sydney, New South Wales, which was opened to the public in 1916 as a popular tourist destination. The segment shows various species of animals, in particular Australian marsupials (including kangaroos and koalas) and reptiles (including a goanna and a green python). The animals are introduced with title cards.

The second section of film shows the Sydney Harbour Bridge and Sydney beaches. The film shows the arched bridge, including views from the top of it, as well as surfing at Bondi, coastal views of Palm Beach and surf lifesaving at Manly.

The third segment shows close-ups of rockpools by the Great Barrier Reef, including crustaceans, sea snails and starfish. It also shows wildlife, including birds and turtles, along the beaches in Queensland.

In the fourth section, the highlights of Perth, Western Australia are shown. The film shows views across the Perth city, King’s Park, the buildings in London Court and the grand buildings of the University of Western Australia.
results.title_for_label: [Taronga Park; Sydney Harbour Bridge; The Great Barrier Reef; Peeping at Perth]

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 7]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film captures a group trip by tourist bus, four wheel drive vehicles and truck around the ‘Gulf Country’. The Gulf Country is the region of woodland and savanna grassland surrounding the Gulf of Carpentaria in north western Queensland and parts of the Northern Territory, Australia.

We see many dirt roads and sandy tracks so that we see both a tourist bus and four wheel drive vehicles being dug out of the sand. As always, Wallace includes close-ups of any flora and fauna that catch
his eye along the way.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 titles ‘A Walkabout Film’, ‘Gulf Country’, ‘A WHC Film’
00:01:15:00 sign for ‘Four Wheel Drive’.
00:01:21:00 a large lorry style truck travelling ahead on dirt road.
00:01:31:00 digging a vehicle out of sand on a track.
00:02:30:00 tourist bus being hauled from the sandy track by a truck.
00:03:42:00 particularly colourful bird in a tree.
00:03:57:00 people in a small boat catching fish.
00:04:55:00 a row of tents for camping lined up along a riverbank.
00:07:45:00 close up of a blackened ‘billy can’ set over a fire and then a wider shot of a group of picnic-goers.
00:08:09:00 a woman in an example of a 1970s style ‘halter-neck’ top.
00:08:32:00 animal footprints in the dust followed by a large snake making progress through the grass
00:09:14:00 large truck and bus with baggage loaded on roof travel down a dusty road
00:09:57:00 cattle in stockyards
00:10:27:00 wetlands and wildflowers
00:11:45:00 swimming in a river
00:11:53:00 a close-up of a spider in the middle of a large web wit the blue of the river in the background
00:12:53:00 title card ‘The End’

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 3]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke.

This film, titled ‘Echuca’, captures a visit to the township of Echuca on the Murray River in Victoria as well as travels along the river itself. Wallace focuses on travelling the river and also on the historic buildings in Echuca itself.

Originally made using Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:05:00 titles ‘WHC Presents’ and ‘Ehuca’
00:00:20:00 paddle steamer travelling on the Murray River.
00:01:26:00 to 00:02:50:00 historic public buildings and houses around Echuca township
00:01:53:00 historic ‘Log Buggy’ in Echuca which holds a felled log from the nearby Moira Forest
00:03:04:00 steam rollers in Echuca
00:04:22:00 Echuca-Moama Bridge over the Murray River
00:05:02:00 motor traffic and streets in Echuca
00:05:04:00 St Mary’s Catholic Church in Echuca
00:05:39:00 Paddle Steamer Adelaide, berthed as an exhibit in the Hopwood Gardens in Echuca, in the 1960s
00:07:58:00 passengers on a paddle steamer on the river
00:08:55:00 water skiing on the river
00:09:03:00 ‘Weir & Lock No 26’ at Torrumbarry
00:10:07:00 logging and sawmill on the riverbank
00:12:35:00 open fire barbeque and picnic on the riverbank
00:13:59:00 examples of fungi along the river
00:14:50:00 group gathering with guitarist at dusk

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 2]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke.

This film, titled ‘Arnhem Land’, contains scenes from a trip to Arnhem Land and Katherine in the Northern Territory in the 1970s.

Travel is by jeep on dusty roads, boats and walking. Wallace captures the varied landscapes of rivers, rocky outcrops, hills, trees, flowers and the scrub as well as termite mounds. He also films buffalo, lizards and waterbirds. A highlight is the Aboriginal rock art drawings throughout the film.

Originally made using Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:05:00 titles ‘WHC Presents’ and ‘Arnhem Land Safari’
00:01:08:00 sign for the township of Katherine in the Northern Territory.
00:02:05:00 truck travels along a dirt road with scrub burning-off on either side.
00:02:29:00 truck travelling crossing a river.
00:02:48:00 pictorial map of the Jim Jim Falls area.
00:03:28:00 canvas tents at a campsite.
00:06:55:00 four wheel drive and trailer.
00:07:52:00 water buffalo.
00:08:00:00 very large bird in equally large nest at the top of a tree.
00:14:30:00 sign ‘Northern Territory Administration Aboriginal Reserve’.
00:13:45:00 examples of Aboriginal rock art drawings which appear until the end of the reel.
00:24:50:00 swimsuits of the era while swimming in a river.
00:27:00:00 digging a tourist bus out of a sandy track.
00:28:58:00 skeletal remains in the mouth of a cave.

results.title: Gaps
results.brief_description:
One of Australia’s finest video artists, Rosetzky’s captivating works have been exhibited widely throughout Australia and internationally. ‘Gaps’ embodies Rosetzky’s ongoing exploration of personal identity and the relationship - or ‘gaps’ - between self and other through speech, movement and dance.

Rosetzky’s collaborators on ‘Gaps’ include choreographer and performer Stephanie Lake, (who also choreographed ‘How to Feel’ 2011) co-writer Anna Zagala, and performers, Jessie Oshodi, Lee Serle, Rani Pramesti and Dimitri Baveas.

Drawing from material Rosetzky gathered conducting interviews with his cast, this new work is an oblique survey of the transition from rehearsal to performance, in both art and life.

The artist’s process involved in-depth workshopping of the material with the performers, who come from acting and dance disciplines. Lake’s choreography, which integrates naturalistic and stylised movements, was also developed with input from the cast and Rosetzky during this rehearsal period. Long time collaborator David Franzke provides the sound design.
results.description:
One of Australia’s finest video artists, David Rosetzky’s captivating works have been exhibited widely throughout Australia and internationally. Gaps embodies Rosetzky’s ongoing exploration of personal identity and the relationship – or ‘gaps’ – between self and other through speech, movement and dance.

Rosetzky’s collaborators on Gaps include choreographer and performer Stephanie Lake, (who also choreographed How to Feel, 2011) co-writer Anna Zagala, and performers, Jessie Oshodi, Lee Serle, Rani Pramesti and Dimitri Baveas.

Drawing from material Rosetzky gathered conducting interviews with his cast, this new work is an oblique survey of the transition from rehearsal to performance, in both art and life.

The artist’s process involved in-depth workshopping of the material with the performers, who come from acting and dance disciplines. Lake’s choreography, which integrates naturalistic and stylised movements, was also developed with input from the cast and Rosetzky during this rehearsal period.

Long time collaborator David Franzke provides the sound design.
description_for_label:
One of Australia’s finest video artists, David Rosetzky’s captivating works have been exhibited widely throughout Australia and internationally. Gaps embodies Rosetzky’s ongoing exploration of personal identity and the relationship – or ‘gaps’ – between self and other through speech, movement and dance.

Rosetzky’s collaborators on Gaps include choreographer and performer Stephanie Lake, (who also choreographed How to Feel, 2011) co-writer Anna Zagala, and performers, Jessie Oshodi, Lee Serle, Rani Pramesti and Dimitri Baveas.

Drawing from material Rosetzky gathered conducting interviews with his cast, this new work is an oblique survey of the transition from rehearsal to performance, in both art and life.

The artist’s process involved in-depth workshopping of the material with the performers, who come from acting and dance disciplines. Lake’s choreography, which integrates naturalistic and stylised movements, was also developed with input from the cast and Rosetzky during this rehearsal period.

Long time collaborator David Franzke provides the sound design.

details.label: Measurements
display_values:
Duration: 35 mins, 7 seconds
The work does not need to be seen from beginning to end, viewers are invited to approach and engage with the work at any point throughout the duration.

production_dates.notes:
Co-commissioned by ACMI and Carriageworks (Sydney).
David Rosetzky: Gaps will be a free exhibition at ACMI from 5 August 2014 to 8 February 2015.
The co-commission of Gaps by ACMI and Carriageworks has been assisted by the Australian Government through the Australian Council for the Arts, its arts funding and advisory body.

results.title: Australian tourism [advertisement]
results.brief_description: Developed by Mojo MDA for the Australian Tourism Commission this advertisement was part of the ‘come and say g’day’ campaign and features Paul Hogan in a range of locations across Australia. It also uses a range of Australian slang expressions including a play on the famous expression ‘put another prawn on the barbie’.

results.title: Orchids of Victoria
results.brief_description: Pictures many different varieties of orchids found growing wild in widely scattered parts of Victoria. Notes the differences among orchids and gives the common and botanical names as well as basic information about each variety.

results.title: Living Hawthorn
results.creator_credit: Millard Johnson, William Alfred Gibson and Johnson and Gibson
results.brief_description: Shows a variety of street scenes in Hawthorn, Victoria, in the early 20th century including shots of Burwood Road, Glenferrie Station, local shops and businesses, traders and residents. Of historical and heritage value. Cinematography by Millard Johnson.
